div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE PROGRESS OF ENGLISH.
div.p: The decision of the Berlin school authorities to substitute English for French as a compul sory subject in the higher classes may be taken as text, at pleasure, for a very narrow or a very extensive discourse. It is recognized by all English scholars that the tradition which gives to French rather than German the premier place as a modern language in our great public schools is a serious inconvenience to the philologist, the historian, or the philosopher, who afterwards discovers that he must acquire laboriously in manhood the knowledge of German which he might have picked up almost unconsciously at school, if he is to keep himself abreast of the latest research. And the scientist who enters on his Univer sity course with no knowledge of German, owing to the exclusive preference shown to French at our public schools, is perhaps still more heavily handicapped. Yet for purposes. of culture it may well be maintained that the French language, with its lucidity, its logic, and its vivacity, supplies the best corrective for some of the faults of a national temperament in whose "Teutonic past" are inherent a certain cambrousness of expression and a certain mistiness of thought. But the more extensive subject which our text suggests has nothing to do with the values of language from the point of view of culture. It was the policy of Culbert, the "big battalions" of Napoleon, not the rare literary qualities of a Corneille or a Voltaire, which raised the French language to an international position. And it is not the privilege of reading Mr. Bernard Shaw's plays in the original that the Berlin school authorities wish to secure for the pupils in their institutions when they propose to make English a compulsory subject.

There can be no stronger proof of the vigour which the Anglo-Saxon race is displaying in the contest for commercial supremacy than the progress which the English tongue is making all over the world. There are some intelligences so obtuse that they misinterpret this palpable fact in a sense which justifies up to the hilt the charges of perverse insularity that are so often brought against us by our Continental friends and critics. The Anglo-Saxon race has other centres of gravity than London, and if the English speech is gradually becoming to the civilized world what the lingua-Franca was to the Levant, a very large part of the oredit and the responsibility devolves upon our American cousins. Still, we may fairly attribute the decreasing importance in the last few years of the knowledge of Spanish for commercial purposes to the characteristic tenacity and determination with which Scotsmen have monopolized the trade of Chili, and the remarkable expansion of British capital enterprise in the Argentine. But while the wide diffusion of a language bears testimony to the activity and success of the race to which it is native, there are pitfalls in this victorious progress. It is the least powerful nationalities which develop the greatest gifts of polyglotism; but the race which, because of its ubiquity and its flourishing circumstances, falls into the temptation of being monoglot loses many advantages. The peoples who for their own interest have to flatter it by learning its langnage console themselves by picking up good things here and there which its complacent ignorance has thrown away. ("The Tribune.")

div.head: Quarantine Board.
div.p: The quarantine board have decided to apply the cholera regulations against arrivals from all Red Sea Ports.

div.head: The Kordofan Ciraffe.
div.p: The Kordofon giraffe born in the London Zoo last week is flourishing-a most charming little animal, the exact likeness of its mother.

div.head: Egyptian Readers.
div.p: Mr. George Robb, of the Tewfikieh School, Cairo, has written Series B. of Macmillan's Egyptian Readers, which has just been published.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and 0.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at half past four this afternoon.

div.head: Egyptian Army.
div.p: The Sirdar, Sir R. Wingate Pasha, will review the Cairo Garrison to morrow morning, at the observatory ground, before his depar ture to the Sudan.

div.head: Roumanian Maritime Service.
Protection of Children.
div.p: Yehia Pasha has accepted the presidency of the newly-formed society whose object is the creation of establishments for the care of. abandoned infants and invalid children of the lower classes.

div.head: Agrioultural Crops.
div.p: Samples of the recent crops of cotton, wheat, and barley, grown in the Oasis of Khargeh by the Corporation of Western Egypt Limited may now be seen at the Corporation's offices in the Sharia Kasr el Nil, by shareholders and others interested.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: There have been only two cases of plague reported for the week ending October 7th: one at Alexandria and one at Beni-Mazar, in the Minieh district. The total number of cases from January to October 7th is 1,102, as against 486 for the same period last year.

div.head: The Semiramis Hotel.
div.p: Two large motor omnibuses, by Cuegier Paris, have arrived in Cairo for the Semiramis Hotel. They are built to carry 12 passengers, exclusive of luggage and servants. and will cover the distance between the hotel and the station in eight minutes.

div.head: Egyptian Cold & Cem Syndicate, Ltd.
div.p: Among the list of company liquidations appearing in the "London Gazette" last week occurrred the Egyptian Gold & Gem Syndicate, Ltd.. The Syndicate was established in February, 1903, with a capital of £36,230 in shares of £1 fully paid.

div.head: Abbate Pasha's Pamphlet.
div.p: The discourse pronounced by Abbate Pasha at the recent meeting of the Khedivial Geographical Society at Athens at the present time, has been republished in pamphlet form and dedicated to Mrs. Athene N. Gianaclis, wife of Mr. Nestor Gianaclis, the cigarette manufacturer.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society.
div.p: A meeting of this Society will be held at the School of Medicine, Kasr el Aini, on Monday afternoon, October 14th, at 4.30 o'clock, when Mr. H. T. Ferrar, M.A., F.G.S., who was geologist to the "Discovery" Antartic expedition (1901-1904), will give an account of some of the results of the expedition's work and will exhibit a large series of lantern slides. Ophthalmio Hospitals in Egypt.

The paper entitled "Four Years' Work with Ophthalmic Hospitals in Egypt" which was read at the annual meeting of the British Medical Association in August last by Dr. A. F. McCallan, chief inspector of ophthalmic hospitals in Egypt, has been reprinted as a pamphlet. It gives an interesting account of the administrative and professional sides of the work done.

div.head: Muelo an Egyptian Art.
div.p: At the meeting of the musical section of the Pan-Celtic Congress at Edinburgh last week, the chairman, Sir William Preece, said that there was no doubt that music originated as an art in Egypt. There were pictures of musical instruments that existed 5,000 years ago. It appeared that the bagpipes, the poor inoffensive bagpipes that were supposed to create so much humour in southern countries, were referred to in the Scriptures under the name of the sackbut.

div.head: Alexandria-Trieste Line.
div.p: The Austrian Lloyd S.S. Company has created upon its Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste service accommodation for fourth class passen

gers on the bridge, without food. The third class has been transformed into a class providing bed and food. The price of the latter, which has up to the present been 75 francs has been raised, to 110 francs for Trieste and 75 francs for Brindisi. The fourth class tariff is 80 francs for Trieste and 72 francs for Brindisi.

div.head: SQUABBLES OF THE PARTIES.
div.p: The organ of our new political party, "Al-Garida," is throwing its supporters on the horns of a dilemma in trying to boast of a splendid but impossible isolation. That newspaper has lived for months without making its existence felt because it affected moderation altogether useless for journalistic life. The result was that "Al-Garida," excellent from many points of view, was not generally appreciated by the public reader and was hardly mentioned among the living papers of the day. Suddenly, the elevation of its shareholders to the dignity of a political party and the loudly advertised programme of that party brought "Al Garida" to prominence for a day or two and made the other Arabic newspapers comment on the new turn, in the tide in a most friendly way. Every important organ of native opinion congratulated the junior contemporary and applauded the new programme declaring that it embodied the views held and proclaimed by the said papers for many years. This did not please "Al-Garida" which apparently wished to claim novelty and initiative in the way of political programmes. It consequently published articles denying all agreement in tone with any prominent paper and ridiculing the idea of having any views in common with such papers as "Al-Mokattam," "Al-Moayad," or "Al-Lewa"; the other papers were not worthy of mention and their approval was of no moment to the last-born but least known of Cairo's daily newspapers. "Al-Moayad" is now engaged in reviling the last-born and revealing its unpardonable price while "Al-Garida" is fighting with both hands striking right and left. This may not be dignifying, but it will certainly make the new venture better known. ("Al Watan").

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: Some of our contemporaries stated that Lord Cromer's project anent the Capitulations is abandoned. But the Alexandria Correspondent of the "Phare d'Alexandrie” denies this and says that Austria and Germany have agreed to it, while France and Italy have shown some reserve.

This reserve cannot be explained as entire rejection. These two powers are considering some modifications that may suit their interests. Mr. Rossetti's mission to the Sudan might have some connection with this ques. | tion. For Italy is now searching for some compensation to counterbalance her approval of Lord Cromer's project in the form of some 1 privilege in the Sudan and its Railways. It also appears that Marquis Salvago-Raggi who was Italy's Agent in Cairo and is now the Governor of Eritrea is leaving for Rome to express his opinions on this subject to Sigpor Tittoni, the Secretary for Foreign Affairs for Italy.

This induces us to assure our readers that Lord Cromer's project is not yet abandoned althoagh we cannot express at the present moment any opinion as to whether it will be convenient to the European residents in | Egypt or not?("Al Ahram.")

It is difficult to ascertain whether the Nationalists, who follow Sh-ikh Aly Youssef and Hafez Awad are as much detested by Mustapha Pasha Kamel as the Egyptian Liberals. The letter of Mohamed Bey Wahid to Sir Edward Grey is considered by Kamel to be as much an act of high treason as the epistle of Hafez Awad to that functionary, especially since his own letter to Mr. Campbell Bannerman has failed to attract any public attention in England. The "Egyptian Standard” remarks:

A word to the authorities in England. | You believe th»t a certain Wabid Ef. is the leader of an Egyptian Liberal Movement. The press, whether upon your instigation or notfor us to decide---published, and in nine cases out of ten, praised a letter supposed to have been sent from Helwan to the Foreign Office. The object of all this intrigue and counterintrigue was to create an opinion in England, an opinion which would take it for granted that the Egyptian National Movement was unimportant, limited to one or two agitators (as you call them) whereas the large body of Egyptiaus, poor, rich, educated, uneducated, recognised Wahid Ef as their leader.

We are willing to test the accuracy of this report. Let Wahid Eff. arrive in Cairo at al given hour. Let his arrival be announced in all the papers ("L'Egypte" included) for at least a week beforehand. Let all his supporters (sic) be entreated, exhorted to be at the station.

How many people, excepting those officials sent by the authorities, do you think would be present to bail the leader (1) of the Liberal Party ? Not a dozen, not ten. We are willing to | wager that not more than half a dozen would put in an appearance! .

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
RAMADAN RECEPTION..
div.p: The Khedive held a reception at Ras-el-Tin s| Palace on the occasion of the beginning of the d[month of Ramadan, 1825

The reception was largely attended by e Government officials of the higher ranks resi. dent in Alexandria and the local Moslem notabilities. Previous to this reception his Highness granted some private audiences.
On Saturday morning his Highness will e receive Sir Eldon Gorst at Ras el Tin Palace. - According to "Al Garida” the Khedive
has definitely decided to reside for at least
four months every year at Alexandria. He will | spend the same time in Cairoand the remaining part of the year in Europe. 15.

div.head: MOTORING IN THE DELTA.
div.p: As a proof of what can be done in a motor a party of English and Americans "left on a | 10 h. p, car from Cairo at 7.30 a.m. and reach
ed Shibin el-Kom at 12.30 p.m. after several stoppages on the way for refreshment. They returned on the east bank of the Nile by the Barrage, arriving at Cairo at 4.30 p.m.

A few days later the same party, which included ladies, left Cairo at 7.30 a.m. in a motor and proceeded by Zagazig to Mansonrah. Next day they went to Tantah arriving at Cairo next evening. The car was a De Dion. There were no accidents, with the exception of a breakdown owing to a burst tyre. The roads were fairly good. On the first trip there were three passengers and the driver, and on the second trip four passengers and the driver.

The. Rev. Robert Somers, B.D., of Moffat, Dumfriessbire, has been appointed by the Co| lonial Committee of the Church of Scotland | to conduct the services in Cairo during the season. The Rev. and Mrs. Somers are expected to arrive in Egypt in time for the first Sunday | in November
The Church will be re-opened on Sunday | 13th October at 10.30 2.m when the first service for the season will be held.

div.head: SUDAN RAILWAYS,
div.p: Some entirely new trains are to be put on | the Wady Halfa-Khartoum line. These trains | are dust-proof and very comfortable. The old | rolling stock used on this route is to be put on | the line from Khartoum to Port Sudan, thus | filling a long felt want and rendering the | journey much more comfortable, as previously | there werə no dining or sleeping cars on this | line, passengers having to carry their own | food, etc.

Ibrahim Pasha, the son of Mohamed Aly, sailed from Alexandria on July 24th, 1824, 'with a squadron of sixty ships of war, a hundred hired transports, and 17,000 disciplined troops against Greece. How the Egyptian | fleet came to grief at Navarino all the world | knows. Now a company is being formed at | Athens (as we recently reported) to explore the bed of the Bay of Navarino in the hope of recovering the remains of the vessels and the treasures of Ibrahim Pasha, their commander, which were lost in the famous battle of October |8, 1827, against the combined fleets of France, England, and Russia.
The attention of speculators have for some time past been turned to this field by the

recovery of a number of gold pieces which were | brought up by some divers, and several | attempts have been made, with the consent of | the Hellenio Government, to find and raise | the Pasha's treasure. Hitherto all such | attempts have failed
The Greek syndicate which has now taken | the venture in hand has concluded a ten years' | agreement with the Government, which would
receive a portion of the immense sumg, which, it is prophesied by those interested, will result from the explorations.
The Greek historian, C. Rados, however, i of opinion that these roseate views are much exaggerated, if not, indeed, entirely fallacions | M. Rados, who is the greatest authority living
on the history of the war of Greek indepen | dence, says it is certain that before the battle
of Navarino Ibrahim Pasha, having a premoni |tion of defeat, placed all his treasures in a safe place, and that the diving syndicate will find very little, if anything.
The Maowen, A. Fawzy, of the Sherbin | district has published a number of poems. The

following are the titles : The Khedive's Birth day, Zoological Gardens (Cairo), The Child and the Moon, Parents' Love, The Boy's Death, The Dog and the Cock, Spring, The Queen's | Death, Evil of War, The Coronation Day, Gizeh Pyramids.
As a specimen of the whole we quote the following lines on the Gizeh Piramids :Though with a mortal hand they were constructed, | Yet immortal thoy seemed to be, Half-hundred hundrod years and more,
Ovuld Gizeh Pyramids see, The nervous aun on high,
"Nervous Snn" is decidedly a happy express sion.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING
APPOINTMENT OF LIQUIDATOR
div.p: Mr. J. B. Gooding, Barrister at Law, 6 Cleopatra St., acting on behalf of certain shareholders of the Bourse and Banking Co. of Egypt Ltd. has notified Mr. Alfred Nahman that his appointment as Liquidator of the said company is conditional and subject to confirmation by the shareholders and cautioning him against dealing in any way with the assets and affairs of the company.
All shareholders who are desirous of combining to ensure their claims under the English Companies Acts are requested to apply to Mr. Gooding at the above address.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN SEASON.
div.p: A correspondent writes to the "Daily Mail" from the Grand Hotel, Paris :- Being one of those individuals who for reasons of health make a pilgrimage to Egypt every winter, I feel it will be of service to others who contem-. plate visiting the land of the Pharoahs to recommend them to make early application for their steamer accommodation, as I was in formed, on applying for a couple of cabins on the new express boats that are to run from Marseille that an extraordinary number of applications for berths are being received. Last year, unfortunately, I had to take my passage by an out-of-date steamer through delay in applying. There must be many whom this will interest.

div.head: AMERICAN OIL FOR EGYPT
div.p: Some new features have just appeared in the streets of Alexandria in the shape of maroon coloured tank wagons, belonging to the Vacuum Oil Company, drawn by mules in smart brown harness. Hitherto the public has been accustomed to the usual green tank carts of Messrs. Worms and the yellow tank carts of Mantaschoff. The new coloured wagons are symbols of the arrival of American oil in Egypt, which is intended to compete seriously with the existing supplies.

div.head: SUDAN TRIBAL AFFRAY.
div.p: The affray which lately took place between the Shaygiyah and the Hassanabs of Bundi Island was due, as we stated in these columns at the time, to some difficulty that ensued between the two tribes about the cultivation of scme lands. We have now learned some particulars about this incident which will no doubt be read with interest.

The Shaygiyah have been in the habit of cultivating some land in Bundi Island, for which they paid an annual rent to the Hassanabs. This year they were refused this privilege by the Hassanabs who are afraid that the Shaygiyah may eventually lay claim to the proprietorship of the land that they have been cultivating, on the ground of occupancy. The latter insisted upon what they have come to look upon as their rights in the land. As neither party was inclined to give way to the other, trouble ensued.

The Government has not yet ascertained the degree of responsibility of either party but the investigations that are being made are hoped to lead to the conviction of those who are responsible for the trouble.

div.head: DETENTION OF UNTRIED PRISONERS IN EGYPT
div.p: Mr. Edward Manson, Joint-Editor of the "Journal" of the Society of Comparative Legislation, in a note in the "Journal" on the above subject, says:

"The figures which the Judicial Adviser of the Egyptian Government gives in his last report as to the detention of untried prisoners may be recommended to the attention of those who are responsible for our circuit system. It is needless to say that the difficulty of obtain ing evidence in criminal cases is much greater in Egypt than in England or in most European countries. But this difficulty is surmounted. Before the establishment of assize courts in Egypt, the average period between the commission of the crime and the sentence was 230 days. In 1905 it had fallen to seventy-one days; in 1906 it was only sixty days. "As far as rapidity of procedare is concerned," remarks the Judicial Adviser with just pride, "Egypt with an average of two months for enquiry and final judgment in all cases of crime, is in advance of many European countries." He adds this interesting note: "Last summer I was in seven continental capitals, viz. Lisbon, Madrid, Paris, Christiania, Stockholm, Copenhagen, and Berlin. In each place I made inquiries as to the average time required in practice for finally disposing of a case of crime. I found that the average of these seven countries worked out at between three and four months.".

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Webb, Under Secretary of State, to the | Ministry of Public Works, has arrived in Cairo
Captain Adams, R.E., General Manager the Delta Light Railways Co. Ltd., is expected back from his holiday in Europe and Canada. - on the 17th inst.
The Rev. N. Odeh, who founded and established Saint Mary's Mission School at Cairo, is shortly leaving Egypt and is to be succeeded by tho Rey T. A Branthwaite, D.D. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Dublin.
Mr. Poole, of the Sudan Government Service, with Mrs Poole and Miss Gordon, have passed through Cairo en route for the Sudan
Captain Poole, of the Sudan Agency, has arrived in Cairo.

The Nationalist vernacular newspapers preserve a significant silence in regard to the letter, which General Ahmed Djellaleddin Pasha wrote from Cairo to The Times." Owing to the fact that the General is the brother-inlaw of Prince Omar Pasha Toussoon and Prince Djemil Pasha Toussoun, it is considered unwise to take him severely to task for his | audacity in having dared to criticise the | Sultan's maladministration, and as the Nationalist Dress is so intimately connected with Yildiz, it is thought discreet to refrain from giving any support to the Pasha's arguments, | although every Egyptian who has visited Constantinople is will aware how well founded are his criticisms Mustapha Pasha Kamel, of course, dare not say a word in support of them as he received his title of Pasha from the

Sultan and is under great obligations to his | Imperial Majesty. | "Al Monyad” is an exception to this policy and indulges in a violent attack on the writer of the letter to "The Times", which would convince the Radical M. P.'s, who are inclined to favour the Nationalists, how closely are the ties which unite them to Yildiz. Unfortunately Mr. Robertson, M. P., and his fellows do not know Arabie.
The engineers of the Nile Valley (New) | Company, have issued the following report :

Development-Driving was resumed in the D. S. level on 19th August, and has advanced 10 ft, making a total distance of 66 ft from the main shaft crossout. The average valae of the reef is 12.44 dwts per ton, over an average width of 28.5 ing. Stoping-The ore stoped during the month was as follows :-Block B. 8. 1, 271.8 tons ; Block B. O., 61.0 tons; Block C. 8.1, 105.7 tons ; Blook C. 8. 2, 265.8 tons; Block C. N. 1, 99.8 tons ; Block D. N. 1, 265.7 tons. Total, 1,068.8 tons. The O. N. 1 stope shows an average value of 19 dwts, due to some coarse gold obtained in the vicinity of the B N. 1 winze, which as far as can be as certained carries down to the C level, but only some 15 ft laterally. Milling-During the month the 10 stamp mill ran for 6,080 stamp hours, treating 1,040 tons of ore, which yielded 478.16 ozs fine gold, exclusive of 2 tons of concentrates, of an assay value of 89.5 dwts per ton. The ore crushed was derived as fola lows :- Development, 12 tons ; stopes, 912 tons ; dumps, 116 tons--1,040 tons.

The coalheavers, or colliers, who coal the ships at Port Said, says a correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette" in contradiction to an article on the 20th inst., are all Arab Moslems, principally from Upper Egypt. They do not eat rice, but live on bread and cheese, pickles, fish, vegetables, and occasionally a little inent. They are remarkably strong, healthy men, and weaklings with "poor, weak lungs" would not be employed. Their earnings amount to about 28. a day. They work in gangs, and after coaling go home to bathe and take their turn of rest: The big liner for India would have its fresh gangs of men. The gambling hell has been closed for many years past, and there are no croupiers. People at Port Said get the usual amount of sleep--much more so than in busy parts of London. The beach is remarkably | clean for a seaport. There is no bloer, very little vice or sin-at least, for twenty years past. Needless injury has been done to it by Kipling and Guy Boothby, but its British and | foreign population are of the usual type of people, enjoying an excellent climate for eight months of the year, and rapid communication with Europe.

The coalheavers, as a rule, do not wenu "turbang," bat some of them tie a strip of handkerchief round their skull caps. The use of betel nut, green or red, is quite unknown. They smoke native tobacco in cigarettes. The coaling is done entirely by men, never by women or children. The idea of women Moslems being employed is ludiorons. The mon in summer are often stripped to the waist, but would never be allowed to go stark naked. These colliera are usually teetotallers, and very rarely indulge in alcohol.

div.head: SULTAN AND AMBASSADOR.
div.p: Rabar, October 8. · Abd el Aziz received yesterday M. Regnault who remitted to him his letters of credit and the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honour.
The Sultan has asserted his desire to restore order in Morocco and to apply the reforms of the Aot of Algeciras, with the valnable assistance of France. M. Regnault was greatly impressed.

Rabar, October 8. M. Regnault and General Liautey have | landed here. They, were rowed ashore by Moors after a great struggle with the surf and were received on the quay by the Moorish Ministers, thousands of the townspeople, and warriors in a variety of uniforms. The Sultan subsequently rode through the streets to meet the mission.
TANQIER, October 8. The envoys who have proceeded to England to obtain Mulay Hafid's recognition will also visit the German and Italian Ambassadors in London.

div.head: ATLANTA COTTON CONVENTION.
div.p: present. Thenselves that Ames but be

Atlanta (Georgia), October 8. A Convention of Cotton Growers and Spinners has opened here. Representatives from Great Britain and the chief countries of Europe are present. The President said he wanted the latter to see for themselves that America could grow all the cotton the world needed, but he admitted the importance of the growers by personal contact with the spinners, realising that to maintain the supremacy they must improve the growing, handling, and marketing and remove abuses.

div.head: SIR ELDON GORST
div.p: PORT SAID, October 9. Sir Eldon Gorst has arrived. He has left for Cairo.

div.head: BALLOON EXPERIMENTS.
div.p: FRIEDRICHSHOFEN, October 8. The King of Wurtenburg, the Crown Prince of Germany, and Archduke Salvator were present at the Zeppelin balloon experiments.
Paris, October 8. The "Matin” states tbat the German Government hag purchased M. Zeppelin's airship for £80,000. She has also ordered another Zeppelin of 205 H.P. capable of carrying 18 persons.

(Reuter) "STUTTGART, October 8. The Zeppelin airship, carrying 8.passengers, mada A anccessful gruise, despite a brisk wind, ayer Lake Constance to-day in the presence of the German Crown Prince and the King of Wartemberg.

div.head: GREEKS AND BULGARIANS.
div.p: SALONIKA, October 8. The assailants åt Negovani were commanded by the chief Tsole. The village was burned. Three women were killed and seven women burned alive. Practically no resistance was offered although a few Greek peasants fired on the Bulgarians from behind a wall. The Turkish authorities promptly arrested 50 Bulgarian peasants in the vicinity. lt
It is stated at Athens that Tsole sent a letter threatening Negovani a month ago but the authorities took no precautions. (Router)
ATHENS, October 8. The continued attacks on Greek villages in Macedonia by Bulgarian bands are causing excitement here.

div.head: THE CONGO BUDGET.
div.p: The Parliamentary Commission has rejected t the motion to submit the Congo budget to the
The Chambers have adopted the Government proposal empowering the King to revise the budget.

div.head: AN ANTI MODERNIST ARCHBISHOP.
div.p: Monsignor Della Chiesa, the prominent anti-modernist, has been appointed Archbishop of Bologna, in succession to the Liberal Cardinal Svampa.

div.head: GERMAN FOREIGN SECRETARY.
div.p: The appointment of Herr Schoen, who is the son of a manufacturer, as Foreign Secretary is applauded in Germany as it shows that high; posts in the country are not the exclusive privilege of the aristocracy. The retirement of Herr Tschirschky is largely for personal motives: he has proved himself to be an utter failure as a debater in the Reichstag. (Reuter)

div.head: DESTRUCTIVE RAINS.
div.p: Heavy rains fell last week in many places, accompanied in some cases with hail. Considerable damage is reported to have been done in the Limassol vine district. This lasted but a day or so and the weather has since been all that the most exacting could desire.

div.head: Use of Manure.
div.p: Farmers are now busy preparing their land for sowing. It is noteworthy how greatly they have come to value their farm yard or khan manure. Only 3 to 4 years ago it was regarded as a "quantité négligeable" in agricultural economy. Very few indeed ever took the trouble to preserve or use it, and any amouut of it could be had for a mere song. That is all now changed. Everywhere farmers have awoke to the realization of its value. The force of example has brought this about. So long as no one used it advice and exhortation were wasted upon them. A practical object lesson has been afforded by the application of manure in the several Government gardens, dispersed about the Island and, by the large demand made upon existing stocks during the last two years by the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co., which has properties in four out of the six districts of the island, and now the native farmers have been roused to follow the lead thus given them.

Just at this season one sees it being drawn out on to the fields, not only near the large towns, but in little out-of-the-way villages. preparatory to being spread in anticipation of the early rains and sowing time. It is becoming no easy matter to obtain it, so tenacious are the farmers of their own stocks, and the Khan proprietors have soon learnt its market value. There is still much indifference and ignorance in regard to the proper manner of 'making' this material, so as to preserve its useful properties; the general opinion being that 'manure is manure.' No doubt its increas ed value will soon lead to greater attention being paid to the methods of keeping it. Chemical manures are still unknown to the average farmer. The Anglo Egyptian Company has imported a certain quantity, and some experimental work has been carried out with nitrates and superphosphates at the Government farm at Athalassa. The time is, doubtless, now approaching when the native agriculturist will find the need of supplementing his slender supply of farm manure with 'artificials.'

div.head: A Burglary Soare
div.p: Several disagreeable alarms have been consed in Troodos this season by attempts made to enter private tents at night, and repeated thefts havet occurred. The culprits have not been caught, which is unfortunate, as their capture would, it is hoped, put a stop to the rumour, which it is difficult to oredit, that the nuisance has been caused by some of the soldiers. On the other hand the native is rarely known to burgle, and as a rale one can leave one's house open at all times with perfect safety. With advancing
civilization, however, one may expect this I primitive condition of things to disappear into | the forgotten past !

div.head: A Poor Animal Show.
div.p: The Annual Animal Show at Omodhos took place on 27th September. As anticipated it was shorn of much of its interest and importance owing to the Troodos season having ended before this date. There were but few English pregent, and the usual lunch provided for them existed only in memory. The number of entries was also not quite up to the mark.

div.head: Prices of Foods. 21
div.p: Prices of nearly all articles of consumption continue a steady rise. To-day corn is selling in Nicosia at the following very high figures : | Wheat 51- per kile, Barley 2/4 , op. per kile; Oats 1/6 cp. per kile and Vetehes 4/6 cp. per kile.

div.head: Personal.
div.p: Mr. H. A. Smallwood, late Island Treasurer, and Mrs. Smallwood and children leave Cyprus this week for England and St. Lucia.

div.head: Mr. Churchill's Visit.
div.p: The "Daily Mail” thus comments on Cyprns | in regard Mr. Winston Churchill's visit:

There is just one little addition which Mr. Churchill has made to the tour which proves the master tourist mind--Cyprus. As it stands | at present, the circular trip embraces Malta|Cyprus-Aden - Mombasa-Nairobi-Uganda
-Gondokpro--the Upper Nile-KhartoumCairo-Malta: Now, the ordinary tonrist hesi. | tates about going to Cyprus - the means of

commmunication may well give bim pause. Few boats and often irregular rons are his fate, and even when he reaches the island the ac. commodation he finds is at present somewhat primitive, while the hopelessly indolent com munity is often – well—-"exacting." Still, there is no more delightful place for a holiday, | Nowhere can one find such superb remains of mediævalism; nowhere, save perhaps, in parts of Greece, can one encounter such delicate instances of refusal to move with the times.

div.head: Development of Cyprus.
div.p: Possibly this accounts for the condition of Cyprus. Under British rule, with, of course, the large tributary payment to the Tark --- A payment which, apparently, many of the Greek inhabitants would like to repudiate - | the island enjoys a medium measure of pros. perity. It is quite true the Greek element think the Millennium would arrive if Great Britain handed Cyprug over to the Hellenic Government. One thing is certain, it would not do better materially. Within the scope of their financial means, the British anthorities are doing good work in the direction of agri. cultural development and especially reafforestation. But Oyprus has ng very great natural

wealth: it ought to be a health resort and || favourite spot for tired tourists, but it takes up | an average holiday to go there and to get away from it. Any ideas, therefore, which Mr. Churchill may be able to contribute towards cheap development will be welcome to all, as this country annually pays the deficit on the island budget. In any case, his presence will

have a stimulating and encouraging effect on | the British administrators, who are too often forgotten and overlooked. Yes, the visit to Cyprus is a good idea, and it ought to be | really comfortable on H.M.S. "Venus."Only let Mr. Churchill beware of the excessively smoothtongued Greek. They are all Front Bench ora
tors down there. | It ought primarily to be clearly stated, of

conrse, that Mr. Winston Churchill's mission to East Africa is a wisely conceived one, in it is equally wisely carried out. Most young colonies have a troublous infancy, and the pre-weaning time of this colony is exception | | ally trying. One can almost imagine the harassed Colonial Office official harking back regretfully to his mind to the days of Si Gerald Portal, and asking in piteous tones why we ever wanted to keep the country at all! Well, we did keep it, and though ever since we have had the most hazy and confused idea: as to what we ought to do there, there is now no one who will maintain that the decision was not right. There is a future before East Africa ; not so great as some anticipate, but still an adequate future. Only that chaos out | there exists is not very reassuring.
On page 7 of to-day's issue a coinpleta list of imports and exports between Egypt and Cyprus will be found.

div.head: NOUZHA GARDENS.
div.p: To Tue Editor Of Thx "Bayptian GazeTTE"

Dear Sir,--Having recently paid one or two visits to the above gardens, it has occurred to me how poorly patronised they are by the European communities of Alexandria, and opon making enquiries have been enrprised to learn how how realise what a delightful rendezvous is within easy access of the city. Sneh was the impression of my first visit that it entirely, changed my opinion of Alexandria, which had hitherte to my mind notone saving consolation, and the only regret I telt iwas that I had not been intueed to go before. A quick run on the teloetric canito Rond Point, from where a motor bus plies to and from the gardens, running along one of the most-pictnr. esque spots in Alexandria, the Mabinoudieh Canal. The gardens themselves are extremely well laid ont, and abound with shady nooks, green patches, and fine avenues, comparing in every respect with our English parks. Refreshments are to be obtained at a reasonable tarif, and a band plays during the afternoon.

div.head: UNE SCENE
div.p: à ce qu'elle le garde elles abso
Monsieur le Directeur de l'Egyptian Gazette."
Monsieur, J'ai assisté ce matin à 10 h. 30 à la porto de Bab el Karasta, à une scène qui m'a donné une drôle d'idée de la façon dont certains agents de la force publique entendent leur role.

Le Gårde Donanier No 66 a arrêté à la porte de la Douane 4 Babel Karasta une voiture à un cheval contenant un monsieur d'aspect fort res. pectable avec ses deux jeunes filles. Ces per sonnes n'avaient avec elles absolument aucun bagage, et le garde en question s'opposait à ce qu'elles sortent de la douane par cette porte en voiture. Ce monsieur fit descendre ses jennes filles et voulut les faire, sortir à pied. Peine inutile; le chawich malappris alla même jusqu'à vonloir empoigner brutalement une de ces demoiselles.

Grâce à l'intervention de personnes présentes et d'autres agents de la Douane, on pervint à faire comprendre à cette brute qu'il avait ontrepassé son rôle. Ces personnes purent sortir à pied et remonter dans leur voiture de l'autre côté de la porte. Pendant ce temps-là, tout le trafic fut arrêté naturellement. | Je ne conçois vraiment pas ce zèle intempestif, surtout vis-à-vis de gens ayant une allure des plus convenables. Il est vrai qu'ils étaient dans une voiture à un cheval ; et j'ai souvent remarqué qu'aux yeux de M.M. les agents douaniers, être dans une voiture à un cheval est souvent suspect. Trôner dans une voiture à deux chevaux est absolument inoffensif.
Malheureusement bien souvent on ne trouve pas toujours en Douane pas plus qu'ailleurs des voitures à deux chevapx.
Je ne doute pas qu'on fasse donner à cet agent quelques leçons de savoir-vivre par un maitre de danse, avant de le poster de nouveau à une isgne aussi importante de la Douane.
Agréez, Monsieur le Directeur, mes salutations distinguées.

div.head: ADVICE TO TIMID INVESTORS.
div.p: Don't lose heart because the shares
You've just bought have sagged away; Who would be the millionaires,
If such trifles brought dismay? Ride as on an Arah steed
Over failure might and main; If at first you don't succeed, Buy, buy, buy again!
Don't imagine, when you deal, Everything will turn to gold: Losses which are very real
Often follow ventures bold. Courage is the thing you need
Golden profits to obtain. If at first you don't succeed, Buy, buy, buy again!
Fortune's but a fickle jade, Smiling now, and frowning then: Don't to woo her be afraid,
Up and woo like other men! When she smiles, she smiles indeed, Gold descends like summer rain. If at first you don't succeed: Buy, buy, buy again!
One bad egg should not dismay, When so many may be sweet What bad luck is yours to-day,
You to-morrow may not meet. Those who fall can only plead,
"It was Fate," but how inane, If at first you don't succeed, Buy, buy, buy again!

div.head: Notices tot eh Advertiser
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct

"It is satisfactory to learn that the Director of Sapplies of the Egyptian Army has just made a contract for 65,000 Indian grain sacks, 2 3/4 lbs., 44"-26 1/2", 8 porters by 9shots, dry sewn, in bales of equal quantities, each bale containing such number as the contractor may wish. These are similar to those known to the trade as Australian wheat bags.”

"It is understood that owing to disputes as to quality which a'most invariably arose with suppliers of Dundee made grain sacks (of which sainples may be seen at this office) the present contract may inaugurate a gradual | displacement of Dandee sacks by Indian sacks for all the purposes of the Egyptian Armyespecialy in the Soudan where a much smaller | and lighter package thau in Egypt is required for handling and transport."

"As regards flour sacks the position seems to be less hopeful at present. The samples remain on view at this office, together with a copy of contract form and specification, but we have no information regarding any successful bid by an Indian inanufacturer for the trade."

From enquiries we have made, it appears that the Egyptian Army formerly bought 2 3/4 1b. grain sacks from Dundee. The price however, this year was too high, and it was, therefore, decided to have samples from Calcutta, with the result that the Authorities accepted a line of 65,000 Australian rorn sacks.

In view, however, of the statements contained in the third paragraph of the cutting, we approached the Director of Supplies to the Egyptian Army with the object of ascertaining, amongst other things, to what extent he was a customer of Calcutta and Dundee, whether, and if so why, he was dissatisfied with the Sootoh bag, and whether there was a serious risk of the Scotch bags being replaced in his Administration by Indian ones. The Director very courteously replied to our enquiries, and with regard to the first point raised he stated "I believe I am correct in saying that the sacks or bags used in the grain and cotton trades in Egypt, and also for tibn, are nearly all imported from India. Consequently we have always purchased these, and have gone to the Scotch manufacturers only for bags for special purposes, which are not readily found on the spot-viz : flour bags--and for bags of a particularly small size and light weight, which also, so far as I know, are pot used in commerce in Egypt, and do not exist in the country-viz ; small 2 lbs grain sacks.”
We gather that the Indian bags purchased by the Egyptian Army during 1905 and 1906 were as follows

With reference to the above figures, the Director stated that the 5 lb bags "are those most generally used, I believe, in the grain trade in Egypt, but they were found too heavy for easy handling in the Sudan, and I do not propose to get any more of them."

"The Indian 2 3/4 lbs bag costs a little more than the Dundee 2 lbs one, bnt the size of the former is 44 by 26 1/2 as against 38 by 21 of the latter. The former, therefore contains considerably more, and will thus, I think, probably prove a considerable economy.

It is perhaps rather unfair to compare the cost of the two, in that the latter were a special line made to our order, while the former are 'apparently largely made in India for the Australian wheat trade."

Perhaps the most serious point in the cutting from the Indian Trade Journal is the allegation that dispntes almost invariably arise in connection with deliveries of Dundee-made grain sacks to the Egyptian Army. The statement in question is, urfortunately, only too true, for the Director of Supplies states that "In any contracts of the recent years for Dundee made sacks, both flour and small grain, there have invariably been disputes on delivery as to quality and weight, and in each contract later deliveries have been better in both respects than the earlier. Hitherto I have not had disputes as to either quality or weight deliverede as regards Indian-made sacks."
As far as we can gather, the Army's principal grounds of complaint in the past re Dundee sacks have been the following:
1. That the bags rapidly and considerably lost weight on being taken from the bales and exposed to the air...
That the thickness of the texture was often inferior to the sample, notwithstanding that the porter and shot were correct.

3. That there was a deficiency in the average weight of the bags comprisiug the whole of| a bale, and that, in certain instances, bags of a heavier quality than those "mentioned in the contract had been inserted in the bales in order, presumably, to bring the gross weights correct.

We do not propose to discuss the question whether the Director of Supplies is justified in regarding that the above complaints are legiti. mate objections to Dundee sacks. We merely state the points, and leave Manufacturers to consider the same.- i

In concluding this article we may just mention the new substitute for jote which it is stated has been discovered in Roumania. The British Vice-Consulat Galatz (Mr. A. J. Ogaton) reports that a large factory, coating from £39,000 to £40,000 is to be built this year at Galate for the manufacture of cellulose' from sword grass, and of a textile yarn from reeds, which can be used for cord and sacking, and is expected to largely replace jute.

div.head: ARMY AND AND NAVY.
div.p: Brigadier General Godfrey, C.B., late of the King's Own Scottish Borderers, now at Cairo, will go on retired pay under the age rules on the 20th inst, and will vacate the appointment of Frigadier General of Administration in the Scottish Command. General Godfrey commanded the 1st Battalion of the Borderers from 1898 to 1902, and led them very straight in South Africa, He subsequently was appointed to the command of the 25th Regimental District, and on giving that up two years ago was appointed to his present billet. He got his C.B. for his services in the South African War.
Lieutenant J. H. Johnston, Royal Garrison Artillery, has been placed on duty with the Egyptian draft for the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps.
Lieutenant R. A. Arkwright, 2nd Battalion Coldstream Guards, has been placed on half pay pro. tem. owing to ill health.
Recruiting is being pushed for the Inniskil ling Dragoons, now at Cairo. A number of very likely inen are being enlisted throughout Ireland, particularly in the North where it was raised in 1688.

The number of British officers serving with the Egyptian Army has now reached the high total of 194. Of these 7 belong to the cavalry, 15 to the Royal Artillery, 20 to the Royal Engineers, 6 to the Foot Guards, 111 to the infantry and the balance to various corps and departments. A short time ago the total was 160.
The battleship "Glory," Captain Robert Phipps Hornby, is en voyage to the Mediterranean to relieve the "Venerable" as flag
ship of Vice-Admiral Prince Lois of Battenberg, second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet.

One of the best of the service papers says that if our navy got the word to move in earnest. not one European Power would dare permit its fleet to leave port." Very satisfactory no doubt in home waters, but a number of our best officers. would like to see more battleships in the Mediterranean, and a few in the Far East. That the Admiralty is beginning to look eastwards is evident by the fact that Esquimalt, British Columbia, is going to be re-occupied as a naval base.

At a sale of war medals at Messrs. Glendinning's no fewer than 60 were put up which belonged originally to the Royal Dublin Fusiliers. So frequently have the medals of this regiment been sold at similar sales that in the opinion of an expert very few of them are now in the possession of the men who earned them. Of course after a man leaves the army his medals are his own property, but in the opinion. of many the retention of such medals should be made a condition of service in the Reserve. A six-bar medal Cape Colony, Tugela, Free States, Ladysmith Relief, etc., was sold with a Northumberland Fusilier medal awarded for service in the Western Transvaal, and the two specimens only realized 30s. A two-bar medal for the Relief of Mafeking (Imperial Light Horse) sold for £1 78. yet a medal for the defence of Kimberley brought the price of 328. A four-bar medal Rhodesia, Transvaal, awarded to Lieut. W. Jiokell, Garrison Artillery,sold for £2 108. In the other section, a 12-bar medal, Peninsula War, was withdrawn at £48, whilst a 11-bar medal of the same period was appraised at £14. Rarity of medals counts a great deal, and the satisfactory sum of £6 58., was paid for a five-bar Egyptian and Sudan medal awarded to Private W. Hogg, of the Royal Highlanders.

On Sunday, when the 1st Yorkshire Regiment, reached Aldershot, on the conclusion of their third autumn manoeuvres, they were, before being dismissed to barracks, formed up on Barossa parade ground, and Brigadier-Gen A.H. Henniker-Major, C.B., commanding the 5th Infantry Brigade, took farewell of them. It was the last occasion he had of seeing them together before they left for service in Egypt. He expressed his great satisfaction at the manner in which all ranks had behaved, and the general smartness and efficiency of the battalion, and, while sorry to part with them, wished them every success in their coming change of station. Your readers will see that the old "Green Howards" go out to Egypt with a magnificent reputation.

A correspondent, commenting on the excellence of the route marching in the recent army manoeuvres, mentions that the battalion of the 1st Yorkshires, which is leaving early in Jannary for Egypt, easily did a march of twenty-one miles on the day after the fighting was concluded, and returned to their quarters on the following day in the pink of condition.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Mardi 8 Octobre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 4 pour cent.

Au Stook-Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé hier de 1/4 à 88 1/2. L'Unifiée a été soutenue à 102 1/4. La National Bank et la Delta Light ont été fermes à 22 et 10 1/2 respectivement. La Daira a haussé de 3/8 à 137/8 et l'Agricole de 1/4 à 8 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu 1 franc à 698. La Banque d'Athènes a gagné 1 franc à 118. Les Lots Tures sont restés à 172.

Ici, le marché a été légèrement plus calme qu'hier. L'animation très forte au début a légèrement fléchi plus avant dans la séance sans que l'approche de la clôture ait amené, comme il est souvent le cas, une recrudescence d'affaires. Le volume des transactions, en dépit de cette légère lourdeur, a été plus que suffisant pour permettre à la généralité de la cote de conserver une grande fermeté, tandis que les valeurs que nous avons vu ces derniers jours très en faveur, en profitaient pour hausser leur cours de quelques fractions.

D'aucuns prétendent, non sans raison, qu'avec la situation saine des marchés européens. et leur tendance haussière évidente, l'Egypte ne saurait faire autrement que d'accuser elle aussi par un relèvement général de ses valeurs, la meilleure situation dans laquelle elle se trouve, surtout ayant trouvé l'appui financier qui lui était nécessaire pour mener à bien la récolte du coton.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank se tasse à 21 15/16. L'Agricole se consolide à 85/16. La Cassa di Sconto remonte à 47. La fondateur Comptoir Financier fléchit à 1 7/8 et la Société Générale Egyptienne à 215.

La Daïra Sanieh poursuit sa hausse à 1311/16. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est calme à 694, sa part de fondateur recule encore à 700 et l'obligation ancienne à 302. La Béhéra hausse à 21 1/4 tandis que l'obligation retombe à 4 3/8. La fondateur Allotment revient à P.T. 60:

La Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux est très recherchée à 3, et la part s'inscrit en bonne tendance à P.T. 61. L'Union Foncière accentue sa reprise à 4 11/16-3/4, ainsi que les Omnibus Automobiles à 2 1/2.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich s'inscrivent en forte hausse à 17 13/16. Les Upper Egypt sont ramenées à 3.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land est ferme à 1 11/16-3/4. Les Estates se maintiennent à 0 11/16 alors que leur part rétrograde à 3. Les Abdy sont plus faibles à 0 1/2 ainsi que les Hooker à 0 3/8-7/16. L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail se présente bien à 21/3-21/6.

On signale de Londres que la situation du marché monétaire apparait plus favorable qu'on ne l'espérait. L'argent qui s'était un peu raréfié en Septembre par suite des besoins d'argent de fin de trimestre, redevient plus abondant et l'on espère que durant le mois d'Octobre l'aisance reparaitra.

D'après des avis autorisés un resserrement n'est pas à craindre pour cet automne. Ia situation de la Banque d'Angleterre est solide comme le montrent ses derniers bilans; la réserve restera élevée sans doute, à moins que n'interviennent des demandes d'or pour le continent ou les Etats-Unis. Quant aux besoins de l'Egypte, de l'Inde, de l'Amérique du Sud, l'Afrique du Sud fournira probablement, et audelà, de quoi y faire face."

L'Amérique qui a donné ces derniers temps de si gros soucis aux financiers européens, semble entrer dans une période financière plus calme. Les dernières informations reçues de là-bas nous apprennent qu'à Wall-Street les capitaux redeviennent assez abondants, et que les banquiers se montraient plus rassurés en ce qui concerne l'avenir immédiat du marché monétaire. Toutefois, à leur réunion annuelle d'Atlantic City, des conseils de prudence ont été formulés. La note dominante des discours prononcés est que la baisse continue de WallStreet a rendu la situation financière beaucoup plus saine qu'il y a un an.

D'Allemagne, la note est également plus rassurante et il est certain que la crise financière dont l'Allemagne était menacée pour octobre sera évitée. Il y a une grande pénurie d'argent, mais les retraits sont plus faibles qu'on ne le pensait. Les Banques ont contribué à étendre les crédits pour permettre aux entreprises industrielles sérieuses de continuer leurs opérations sans nouvelles avances. L'état du marché s'est amélioré également sous l'iafluence du prompt paiement par les Américains des marchandises expédiées chez eux.
Telles sont tout au moins les déclarations qui résultent des interviews de banquiers allemands.

MM. les actionnaires de l'"Egyptian Land and General Trust Ltd. " dont les certificats provisoires ne seraient pas encore endossés avec constatation du paiement des appels, sont instamment priés de présenter immédiatement leurs certificats, en y joignant les reçus des banques concernant les dits appels,aux bureaux de la compagnie, 10 Sharia Zervudachi, afin qu'il y soit procédé

The Company's Shop in the SHARIA BOULAC is still open for Retail Trade in Cairo.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer et Té égraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'à partir du 10 Octobre courant, les Bureaux télégraphiques suivants ne fermeront pas de 1 à 3 p.m., excepté les Dimanches :

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways Administration has the honour to inform the Public that the new Station at Bouche will be opened on Saturday, October 12th at 11 30 a.m., and all trains after this hour will start from the new Station.
Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et élégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à connaissance du Public qu'il sera procédé le amedi dix-neuf Octobre courant, à neuf heures u matin, au bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des fagasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie), à la vente ux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, es vieux articles se trouvant à Gabbary, où
peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf eures du matin à midi, les Dimanches et ars fériés exceptés. Les conditions de vente ainsi que la liste lative à ces matériaux peuvent être consultées

Bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des agasins Généraux à Boulac, Caire, et à celui de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary, Alexandrie, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m., les Dimanches et jours riés exceptés.
Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionire devra, au préalable, verser à la Caisse entrale de l'Administration au Caire une

mme de L.E. 10 (Dix Livres Egyptiennes) à re de dépôt provisoire. Le sonmissionnaire claréadjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme squ'a concurrence de 10% (dix pour cent) montant de l'offre agréée et enlever à ses is les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans un lai de trente jours à compter de la date de Avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront être faites sur papier mbré de trente milièmes si l'intéressé ne peut 8 assister aux enchères publiques, et dans ce s la soumission ainsi que le reçu du verseent du dépôt provisoire susdit seront adressés r la poste sous pli recommandé à: Monsieur l'Inspecteur des Magasins des Chemins de fer de l'Etat
et soda donble enveloppe, l'intérieure portant I la suscription suivante :
"Offre pour achat de vieux articles" Toate ofire faite on déposée mitérieurement an jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pae prise en considération.
D'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la | connaissance du Pablio qu'il sera procédé, le

Jeudi, dix Octobre prochain, à neaf heures du matin aux Magasins Généraux de Boulac, | (Caire), à la vente aux enchères publiques, soivant Kaimat Mazad, d'une quantité de soixante et un mille kilogs, environ de vieux bois et d'une quantité de 746 vieilles traverses qui se trouvent aux Magasins No. 1 de l'Administration, à Boulac, où on peut les examiner | chaque jour de neuf heures du matin & midi, | le Dimanche et jours fériés exceptés. | Les conditions de vente relatives à ce maté Triel peuvent être consultées au Bureau de
Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux 1 à Boulac, Caire, et à celui de Mr. l'Inspecteur
des Magasins de Gabbary, Alexandrie, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p. m. le Dimanche et jours fériés exceptés.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au préalable, verser à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration an Caire, une somme de L.E. 18 (Treize Livres Egyptiennes) là titre de dépôt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire
déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrenceda 10%(dix pour cent) du montant de l'offre agréée et enlever à ses
frais les lots qui lui seront adjagés dans un | délai de trente jours à compter de la date de | l'Avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront être faites sur papier timbré de trente millièmes si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchères publiques, et dans ce cas la sumission ainsi que le reçu du versement du dépot provisoire susdit seront adressés par la poste sons pli recommandé à : Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux
des Chemins de fer de l'Etat
& Bonlac (Caire) et soul double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription snivante : "Offre pour Achat de Vieux Bois et Traverses."
Tonte offre faite on déposée ultérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des. Chemins de fer et Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter å la connaissance du public qu'elle recevra jug. qu'au Jeudi, 17 Octobre 1907, à midi au plns tard, des offres pour la fourniture en vrào og en bidons, du pétrole raffiné de Russie dont l'Administration aura besoin pendant une période de six mois, conformément aux conditions dont on peut prendre connaissance au Caire an Service Central deg Magasins Généraux à Boulac et à Alexandrie au Bureau de M. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary.
Les soumissionnaires auront à joindre à leur offre un récépissé constatant le versement à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire, d'un dépôt provisoire de L.E. 100 (Livres Egyptiennes cent).
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une | fenille de papier timbré de trente Millièmes. Elles seront adressées par la Poste sons pli re. commandé à :
Monsieur le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux, Chemins de fer de l'Etat.
Bonlac, (Le Caire). et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant
la suscription suivante :-- | "Ofire pour la fourniture de pétrole de | Russie." | L’Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter | l'offre la plus basse, ni à donner suite aux son
missions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de | diviser la commande. | Le Caire, le 2 Octobre 1907. 31039-2-2
